children.value: See the a detailed specification of the
Applications can also create new loader objects. E.g. if you have existing JavaScript parsing functionality that you would like to use with the loaders.gl core utility functions.
You would give a name to the loader object, define what file extension(s) it uses, and define a parser function.
Short name of the loader ('OBJ', 'PLY' etc)
Three letter (typically) extension used by files of this format
Guesses if a file is of this format by examining the first characters in the file
A loader must define a parser function for the format, a function that takes the loaded data and converts it into a parsed object.

Depending on how the underlying loader works (whether it is synchronous or asynchronous and whether it expects text or binary data), the loader object can expose the parser in a couple of different ways, specified by provided one of the parser function fields.
In general, it is recommended that loaders are "standalone" and avoid importing
provides a small set of shared loader utilities.
loaders.gl enables loaders to call other loaders (referred to as "sub-loaders" in this section). This enables loaders for "composite formats" to be "composed" out of loaders for the primitive parts.
Good examples of sub-loaders are the
which can delegate Draco mesh decoding to the
and image decoding to the various
Naturally, Composite loaders can call other composite loaders, which is for instance used by the
to parse embedded glTF data in certain tiles.
To call another loader, a loader should use the appropriate
A conceptual example of a 3D Tiles loader calling the
While a loader could potentially import
to invoke a sub-loader, it is discouraged, not only from a dependency management reasons, but it prevents loaders.gl from properly handling parameters and allow worker-loaders to call other loaders.
